articles.headline: Misery Hangs Over Gaza Despite Pledges of Help
articles.snippet: Lately cut off from any productivity or hope, Gaza will soon be back at the center of Mideast peace negotiations.
articles.abstract: Lately cut off from any productivity or hope, Gaza will soon be back at the center of Mideast peace negotiations.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA  Dozens of families still live in tents amid collapsed buildings and rusting pipes. With construction materials barred, a few are building mud-brick homes. Everything but food and medicine has to be smuggled through desert tunnels from Egypt. Among the items that people seek is an addictive pain reliever used to fight depression.

articles.headline: In Finland, Nuclear Renaissance Runs Into Trouble
articles.snippet: A Finnish project suggests a new generation of reactors will be no easier or less costly to build than in the past.
articles.abstract: A Finnish project suggests a new generation of reactors will be no easier or less costly to build than in the past.
articles.lead_paragraph: OLKILUOTO, Finland  As the Obama administration tries to steer America toward cleaner sources of energy, it would do well to consider the cautionary tale of this new-generation nuclear reactor site.

articles.headline: Microsoft’s Search for a Name Ends With a Bing
articles.snippet: Microsoft hopes Bing, the name of its new search service, eventually becomes a verb, like Xerox and, well, Google.
articles.abstract: Microsoft hopes Bing, the name of its new search service, eventually becomes a verb, like Xerox and, well, Google.

articles.headline: It’s Thankless, but He Decides Madoff Claims
articles.snippet: Irving Picard oversees claims in the Madoff case, deciding who will be paid quickly, who will be paid eventually, who will not be paid at all. It is not a job for the thin-skinned.
articles.abstract: Irving Picard oversees claims in the Madoff case, deciding who will be paid quickly, who will be paid eventually, who will not be paid at all. It is not a job for the thin-skinned.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Ponzi scheme’s victims denounce him as cold-hearted, dishonest and just plain wrong.

articles.headline: Still Working, but Making Do With Less
articles.snippet: For millions of families, the recession has not meant a layoff, but a pay cut that has forced them to thrash through daily calculations.
articles.abstract: For millions of families, the recession has not meant a layoff, but a pay cut that has forced them to thrash through daily calculations.
articles.lead_paragraph: LINCOLN, Calif.  The Ferrells have cut back on dance lessons for their twin daughters. Vaccinations for the family’s two cats and two dogs are out. Haircuts have become a luxury.

articles.headline: Credit Relief May Not Last Long
articles.snippet: The worst of the credit crisis appears to be over, but enthusiasm may still be getting ahead of reality.
articles.abstract: The worst of the credit crisis appears to be over, but enthusiasm may still be getting ahead of reality.
articles.lead_paragraph: The experience of being choked to death can concentrate a person’s attention. When the chokehold is removed, a feeling of relief, perhaps even of exhilaration, is to be expected.

articles.headline: Pentagon Plans New Arm to Wage Cyberspace Wars
articles.snippet: The armed forces have stepped up preparations to conduct both offensive and defensive computer warfare.
articles.abstract: The armed forces have stepped up preparations to conduct both offensive and defensive computer warfare.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon plans to create a new military command for cyberspace, administration officials said Thursday, stepping up preparations by the armed forces to conduct both offensive and defensive computer warfare.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Nominee’s Links With Advocates Fuel Her Critics
articles.snippet: Sonia Sotomayor’s work as a board member of the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund may become an issue during her confirmation hearings.
articles.abstract: Sonia Sotomayor’s work as a board member of the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund may become an issue during her confirmation hearings.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund sued the New York City Police Department, claiming that its promotion exams discriminated against Latinos and African-Americans.
articles.byline: By Raymond Hernandez and David W. Chen

articles.headline: Prime Minister’s Escapades Finally Raise Eyebrows
articles.snippet: The debate over Silvio Berlusconi is not just about sex, but critics say, reflects an inattention to Italy’s deep problems.
articles.abstract: The debate over Silvio Berlusconi is not just about sex, but critics say, reflects an inattention to Italy’s deep problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME  When the wife of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi took to the front pages this month to announce that she wanted a divorce and accused him of dallying with very young women, it seemed like yet another storm that Italy’s most powerful man would easily weather. For years, Italy has winked at Mr. Berlusconi, where other nations might have glared.

articles.headline: 2 Auditors Held in India Fault System
articles.snippet: Four months after the revelation of a massive fraud at Satyam, two independent auditors from PricewaterhouseCoopers, who maintain their innocence, remain in prison.
articles.abstract: Four months after the revelation of a massive fraud at Satyam, two independent auditors from PricewaterhouseCoopers, who maintain their innocence, remain in prison.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHANCHALGUDA, India  Hyderabad’s Central Prison is no country club jail.

articles.headline: In Global Shift, G.M. Plans Sale of Europe Unit
articles.snippet: An unlikely Canadian-Russian alliance tentatively agreed to buy the European operations of General Motors in a deal that would have effects in the U.S.
articles.abstract: An unlikely Canadian-Russian alliance tentatively agreed to buy the European operations of General Motors in a deal that would have effects in the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: The global reordering of the auto industry took a big step forward on Friday as an unlikely alliance led by Magna International, a Canadian auto parts maker, and Sberbank of Russia tentatively agreed to buy the European operations of General Motors.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Carter Dougherty
